iss-tutorial.text: Hello there, space explorer! My name is Neil DePaws Tyson, and I'll be your guide on this journey. Welcome to the International Space Station tutorial!
First, let's learn how to move your spacecraft. Use the arrow keys on your keyboard to navigate through space.
Your spacecraft runs on fuel! Every time you move, you consume fuel. Keep an eye on your fuel gauge in the top right corner.
If you run out of fuel, you'll stop moving and drift in space. Always make sure you have enough fuel to reach your destination!
The International Space Station, or ISS, orbits Earth at about 408 kilometers above the surface, traveling at 7.66 kilometers per second!
The ISS serves as a microgravity laboratory where astronauts conduct experiments in biology, physics, astronomy, and more.
To refuel your spacecraft, you need to dock at the ISS. Navigate your ship close to the station - you'll see it when you're near!
Before you can refuel, you'll need to answer some questions about the ISS. Don't worry - you can try as many times as you need!

password-hint.text: Hold on! The pump is locked. We need to bypass the security protocols to refuel.
I'm patching you into the system. The password is hidden inside the text log.
Here is a hint: Look for words written in ALL CAPS. Combine them together to form the password!

refuel-success.text: Excellent work! You've successfully refueled. Now you're ready to continue your journey through space.
